subject: RE: [junit] Re: Conditional tearDown()
msgSnippet: No argument there... It sounded like that would be conditional logic though -- in which case it is test dependency. =jason [:question | ^One] ... Outgoing mail

No argument there... It sounded like that would be conditional logic
though -- in which case it is test dependency.

=jason
[:question | ^One] 

  >  -----Original Message-----
  >  From: Kendall Collett [mailto:przkiie02@...] 
  >  Sent: Friday, January 03, 2003 1:25 PM
  >  To: junit@yahoogroups.com
  >  Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Conditional tearDown()
  >  
  >  
  >  So far, I haven't needed to visually inspect the DB; I 
  >  just want to keep that option open in the case of a test failure.
  >  
  >  WRT test dependencies, the pre-clean approach amounts to 
  >  having setUp() having knowledge of what state should be 
  >  cleaned-up to avoid perturbing its testcase vs. having 
  >  tearDown() having knowledge of what state was changed by 
  >  its testcase (so that it can clean up to avoid perturbing 
  >  the next testcase).
  >  
  >  Kendall
  >  
  >  ----- Original Message -----
  >  From: "Jason Rogers jacaetevha-at-fast-mail.org |Yahoo 
  >  Work 20030102|" <i9w4h85g3o0t@...>
  >  To: <XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX>
  >  Sent: Friday, January 03, 2003 11:42
  >  Subject: RE: [junit] Re: Conditional tearDown()
  >  
  >  
  >  > Could you not use the opportunity to clean up your code 
  >  such that you 
  >  > don't need to visually inspect the DB?  I realize that 
  >  there may be 
  >  > times when you absolutely need the visual inspection 
  >  (though I can't 
  >  > think of one off the bat), nevertheless, this seems like 
  >  a subtle form 
  >  > of test dependencies or spaghetti code, or some other 
  >  code-smell.  
  >  > Sorry if that sounds harsh -- I am certainly not trying to be 
  >  > judgemental, just reflective.
  >  >
  >  > =jason
  >  > [:question | ^One]
  >  >
  >  > -----Original Message-----
  >  > From: Kendall Collett [mailto:przkiie02@...]
  >  > Sent: Friday, January 03, 2003 12:41 PM
  >  > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
  >  > Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Conditional tearDown()
  >  >
  >  > I could use a conditional clean-up in tearDown, for 
  >  exactly the same 
  >  > reason as Brian.
  >  >
  >  > When I first ran into this issue; I didn't think of 
  >  trying to make the
  >  > tearDown() clean-up conditional.  Instead, I adopted a 
  >  convention of 
  >  > having my setUp()s perform the clean-up for the next 
  >  test.  In other 
  >  > words, for a given test I do a pre-clean instead of a 
  >  post-clean. I'm 
  >  > not sure if that's good or bad...
  >  
  >
